name: Broiled Pork Chops with Rosemary and Fish Sauce
description: For best flavor, select fatty chops for this recipe. You’ll be sorry if you go lean or use boneless chops. Gnawing on the bone is the cook’s bonus!
recipeIngredient: 2  thick-cut bone-in pork chops ((1 ½ pounds total))
2 tablespoons canola or other neutral oil
1/2 cup Nuoc Cham Dipping Sauce ((optional, see Note))

recipeInstructions.text: Pat the pork chops dry and set aside on a plate or in a zip-top plastic bag.
recipeInstructions.name: Pat the pork chops dry and set aside on a plate or in a zip-top plastic bag.

recipeInstructions.text: Strip the leaves from a 5-inch sprig of rosemary, dropping them into a small food processor. Set the remaining rosemary aside. To the processor, add the onion, garlic, sugar, salt, paprika, pepper, turmeric, fish sauce and 1 tablespoon oil. Whirl into a puree. Scrape onto the pork and spread it all around. Cover (or close the bag) and refrigerate for 2 hours or up to 24 hours. Let sit at room temperature for about 30 minutes before cooking.
recipeInstructions.name: Strip the leaves from a 5-inch sprig of rosemary, dropping them into a small food processor. Set the remaining rosemary aside. To the processor, add the onion, garlic, sugar, salt, paprika, pepper, turmeric, fish sauce and 1 tablespoon oil. Whirl into a puree. Scrape onto the pork and spread it all around. Cover (or close the bag) and refrigerate for 2 hours or up to 24 hours. Let sit at room temperature for about 30 minutes before cooking.

recipeInstructions.text: Position a rack in the top third of the oven (aim for the pork to cook about 5 inches from the heat source), and set the oven to broil. Line a small baking sheet with foil and place a rack on top. Scrape the marinade off the pork (reserve it for other uses; see Note below) and gently blot moisture from the pork. Place the pork on the rack and drizzle the remaining 1 tablespoon of oil.

Line a small baking sheet with foil and place a rack on top. Scrape the marinade off the pork (reserve it for other uses; see Note below) and gently blot moisture from the pork. Place the pork on the rack and drizzle the remaining 1 tablespoon of oil.

recipeInstructions.text: Broil the pork chops for 5 to 6 minutes per side, or until browned at the edge and a meat thermometer inserted registers about 145F. At the end, I like to broil the first side for about 45 seconds extra to refresh it.

recipeInstructions.text: Put the remaining rosemary on a plate and set the pork chops on top. Loosely tent with foil, a domed lid or inverted bowl. Let sit for 5 to 10 minutes before slicing and serving with the dipping sauce, if you like.

review.reviewBody: The pork chops sound like something I want to try. But I also wanted to say your new kitchen looks fabulous! I don't know if you had to be the "boss lady" much but it looks like your workers respected your wishes. Congratulations Andrea. So glad your parents pulled through their Covid struggles successfully. I can relate.

Andrea, Thank you for this. It is a great blessing to hear that your parents are recovering. Your father's Christmas wisdom that you shared here touched my heart, and we all need more good news. At our house we have also been cooking for stress relief. Our youngest son, home from university for winter break, received your Vietnamese Food Any Day for Christmas and cooked for us. Spicy sweet pomegranate tofu was magnificent! Thank you again!
